name: The Twilight Walk London 2026
short_description: This iconic walk will see the brain tumour community unite to take strides through the Capital, as we reflect, remember and raise money.

raw.title: The Twilight Walk London 2026
raw.desc_preview: This iconic walk will see the brain tumour community unite to take strides through the Capital, as we reflect, remember and raise money.
raw.full_description: This iconic walk will see the brain tumour community unite to take strides through the Capital, as we reflect, remember and raise money. T he Twilight Walk is back for 2026 ! Will you join us? This March, people from across the UK will come together to raise money and stride towards cures for all brain tumours. Join us at The Twilight Walk London on Saturday 21 March, every step you take and every pound you raise will move us further, faster towards a brighter future for people affected by a brain tumour. The Twilight Walk London is our biggest fundraising event of the year, as we bring together more than 1,300 members of the brain tumour community to give the boot to brain tumours. You can choose from two beautiful, stewarded routes - either 5km or 10km ‚Äì that both begin and end at Lindley Hall in Westminster, where you can soak up the festival atmosphere and enjoy food, entertainment and live music. Last year the community raised a whopping ¬£532,349. We know that together, we can push above and beyond that in 2026. By all of us walking and fundraising together, we can make sure everybody diagnosed with this awful disease in the future lives a longer, better life. Will you help us pick up the pace of progress urgently needed by the brain tumour community?

Wildlife and seasonal themed activities for teenagers to explore and engage in the great outdoors! Sessions last for 2 hours and are packed full of activities to teach you about the natural world that surrounds you. Over the course of a year, you can expect to: üå≥ Learn about wildlife including insects, plants, birds and mammals üå≥ Complete valuable conservation work and learn how to use tools safely üå≥ Develop bushcraft skills including fire lighting and campfire cooking This club is for children only - no adults to accompany please. A consent form must be completed and returned for each child before the session - details will be sent after booking. We are committed to keeping our visitors, staff and volunteers safe. Please DO NOT allow your child to attend if they are unwell, or testing positive for an infectious illness, such as COVID-19. Your consideration is hugely appreciated. short_description: Join Neal Glucksmann0Smith for a winter hike to walk part of the Big Walk starting from Chingford to Wanstead.

raw.title: A Linear Walk between Chingford and Manor Park - Guided Walk
raw.desc_preview: Join Neal Glucksmann0Smith for a winter hike to walk part of the Big Walk starting from Chingford to Wanstead.
raw.full_description: Join Neal Glucksmann0Smith for a winter hike to walk part of the Big Walk starting from Chingford to Wanstead. About the walk Join Neal Glucksmann-Smith to walk part of the Epping Forest Big Walk from Chingford to Wanstead. This will be a longer walk with moderate pace where we will walk through ancient wood pasture, Highams Park Lake and reach open landscape of Hollow Ponds and Wanstead Flats. Bring lunch, snack, water. Meet: Outside Queen Elizabeth‚Äôs Hunting Lodge, E4 7QH. This is a short walk from Chingford station (Weaver Line). What3words : duck.bills.atoms Endpoint: The walk will finish at Manor Park, the southern end of Epping Forest. It‚Äôs at the junction of Forest Drive and Capel Road, near Manor Park Station. Google Map location here . About EFHT and our Guided Walks in Epping Forest Join our Guided Walks to discover more of Epping Forest and its ecology, heritage and cultural. Walks are led by our expert volunteer leaders. Some are a gental stroll, whilst others are taken at a faster pace. Each walk tends to focus on a small part of the Forest, and sometimes with specific themes ranging from local histry to natural environment. About Epping Forest Big Walk Epping Forest Big Walk is our annual celebration walk where we walk the continuous length of Epping Forest from Manor Park in East London to Bell Common in Epping in one day. Whether you are a first-timer or a returning walker, join people from all walks of life to walk through the wonderful Epping Forest, get to know this rare surviving piece of ancient woodland, and celebrate its irreplaceable biodiversity, culture and heritage. Previously known as ‚ÄòThe Centenary Walk‚Äô, the route was first devised by Fred Mattews from the West Essex Ramblers and Harry Bitten from the Friends of Epping Forest in 1978 to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the passing of the Epping Forest Act in 1878. Epping Forest Big Walk returns every September and is one of the biggest annual events celebrating Epping Forest and its heritage. To find out more about the Big Walk, please visit here . This project is made possible thanks to National Lottery funding.

Join us for a live panel discussion exploring the future of UK food systems, food prices, and the vital role nature must play in creating resilient, healthy diets for all. Our food supply chains should deliver healthy, sustainable and affordable food, but they often fall short. raw.desc_preview: How do you want to change the world?
raw.full_description: How do you want to change the world? The Girls Human Rights Festival 2026 proudly presents Girls as Peacebuilders and Negotiators, a powerful day dedicated to equipping young women with the skills to influence dialogue, resolve conflict, and lead peacebuilding efforts worldwide. This event will highlight the crucial role girls and young women play in creating just, inclusive, and sustainable societies. The day features the Masterclass by CEDR, designed to provide participants with practical tools to influence public policy and drive social change through advocacy. Attendees will gain insights into the lobbying process, ethical considerations, coalition building, and strategies for engaging decision-makers effectively. With expert speakers and real-world examples, this session will give participants the confidence to amplify their voices and make a meaningful impact. The day begins with a warm welcome and registration at 14:30, where participants will have the chance to settle in with tea before diving into a packed programme. At 14:45, the All-Stars Panel on Girls as Peacebuilders will open the event, featuring powerful conversations with inspiring leaders and advocates. Networking and coffee at 15:45 will offer the perfect chance to connect with fellow participants, share ideas, and build lasting connections. The highlight of the day follows at 16:00, with the Masterclass on Skills for Peacebuilding and Negotiation led by the Centre for Effective Dispute Resolution. This session will provide practical tools and techniques for negotiation, mediation, and conflict resolution that can be applied to both local and global contexts. The event will close at 16:45 with a final opportunity for networking, where participants can meet sponsors, speakers, and other changemakers shaping the future of peacebuilding. This event is open to anyone aged 17 and above who is passionate about human rights, peacebuilding, and advocacy. Whether you are an aspiring lobbyist, a student, or a young leader eager to create impact, this programme will help you build essential skills to lead change in your community and beyond. Our lineup of speakers will be announced soon. name: Faith, Refugees and Migration
short_description: The Woolf Institute invites you to join us for a one-day interdisciplinary research symposium.

raw.title: Faith, Refugees and Migration
raw.desc_preview: The Woolf Institute invites you to join us for a one-day interdisciplinary research symposium.
raw.full_description: The Woolf Institute invites you to join us for a one-day interdisciplinary research symposium. Across the globe, migration and displacement continue to shape societies and challenge political, ethical, and social frameworks. Questions of belonging, identity, and hospitality have come to occupy a central place in public debate, while religious communities have been both participants in, and respondents to, these shifting realities. This symposium seeks to provide a space for thoughtful, rigorous, and constructive dialogue on how faith leaders and communities engage with issues of migration, asylum, integration, and diversity. Welcoming presentations across academic disciplines and practitioner perspectives, the symposium will explore how faith informs responses to the movement of people, and discuss how best to foster collaboration and deepen understanding of the ethical and social dimensions of migration in the modern world. A full symposium programme will be announced in the new year. The Woolf Institute invites you to join us for a one-day interdisciplinary research symposium. raw.title: Road to Gilead - Open Space Event
raw.desc_preview: Join the Guilty Feminist community for an energising event exploring grassroots action to resist the rise of the far right.
raw.full_description: Join the Guilty Feminist community for an energising event exploring grassroots action to resist the rise of the far right. Utilising Open Space methodology, this  event will enable like-minded collaborators to explore and create grassroots actions to resist the rise of the far right, Christian nationalists and ethno-nationalism. We may well be on the Road to Gilead, but together, we can turn things around! This is your invitation to rise, collaborate, and reimagine what‚Äôs possible. Join the Guilty Feminist community for an energising event exploring grassroots action to resist the rise of the far right. Utilising Open Space methodology, this  event will enable like-minded collaborators to explore and create grassroots actions to resist the rise of the far right, Christian nationalists and ethno-nationalism. We may well be on the Road to Gilead, but together, we can turn things around! This is your invitation to rise, collaborate, and reimagine what‚Äôs possible. This event welcomes everyone resisting ‚ÄúThe Road to Gilead‚Äù. is shorthand for an oppressive far-right future as envisioned by far-right ‚ÄúChristian‚Äù nationalists who wish to take our reproductive rights, restrict LGBTQ+ rights and create an ethnonationalist state. We wish to welcome people of no faith, all faiths and faith-based communities. We want to create a coalition of like-minded citizens who want a more equitable, compassionate, connected society. Let‚Äôs get inspired and organised and build the world we want to live in. This is your invitation to rise, collaborate, and reimagine what‚Äôs possible! The Open Space method allows individuals to bring ideas, projects, problems and challenges and break into small groups to tackle them. You can come with ideas or just a willingness to engage, discuss and problem solve. Our hope is to see several grassroots projects find legs through this day, as well as encouraging connections for future endeavours. Discussion is wonderful and action is necessary. This is for folks who wish to join us in person for the full day of activities. Lunch and hot drinks will be provided. If cost is a barrier to attend this event, we have free tickets available. Please email activistevents@amnesty.org.uk to request one. Choose this option if you‚Äôre unable to join us in person on the day but would like to take part remotely. You'll be able to attend the two plenary sessions (currently scheduled for 11am and 3:45pm). We also encourage you to gather your own group of interested people (in your town, or any community you are part of) and feedback your ideas/hear the in-person groups' contributions at the end of the day. We are planning online break-out rooms for discussions - more details to follow. The link for joining us online will be shared with you in advance of the event. raw.full_description: Experience a night of what homelessness feels like and raise awareness and funds to help those people sleeping rough in your city every day. Homelessness can happen to anyone, at any time, and for various reasons. For one night you can gain insight into what that feels like by taking part in our sleep out. Together we can help make Peterborough a better place for all by raising awareness of homelessness and raise vital funds to support those experiencing it every day. So will you brave a night in the cold?.... Register your place and join us on Thursday 19th March 2026 at 6:30pm, at Peterborough Cathedral. There'll be people with lived experience of homelessness as well as live entertainment. You will also wake up with a pastry and hot drink in the morning. We kindly ask you to raise as much as you can in sponsorships. You can do so by setting up a fundraising page from our . For health & safety and Safeguarding reasons, this event is not suitable for those under 16 years old. For those under that age or unable to come to the Cathedral, you can do your own sleepout at home, workplace or school and still get involved fundraising for us. name: SEND Collective
short_description: Work alongside sector leaders to develop SEND and neuroinclusion strategies. Co-create the policies that will guide FE and Skills Sector

raw.title: SEND Collective
raw.desc_preview: Work alongside sector leaders to develop SEND and neuroinclusion strategies. Co-create the policies that will guide FE and Skills Sector
raw.full_description: Work alongside sector leaders to develop SEND and neuroinclusion strategies. Co-create the policies that will guide FE and Skills Sector When educators and leaders are equipped with the tools, trust, and professional development they need, they can focus on what they do best: teaching, guiding, and inspiring learners to overcome barriers and achieve their potential. This event offers a timely and practical exploration of how trauma-informed, inclusive, and motivational teaching practices can help address the growing pressures across the further education and skills system for all learners, whether they are progressing from school to college, starting an Apprenticeship, or those returning to learning as adults. While support remains uneven across the system, our focus is on building the confidence and capacity of educators and leaders to respond effectively to diverse learner needs within a system-wide culture of inclusion. Drawing on current policy and research evidence, the event will explore how inclusive practice can underpin equitable access, participation, and achievement across the learner journey. Attendees will engage with, for example, practical approaches including reasonable adjustments for Apprentices and employers, adaptive assessment strategies that uncover hidden barriers to learning (particularly in English, maths, and digital inclusion), and approaches to address the intersections between SEND, neuro-inclusion, and socio-economic disadvantage. Breakout sessions will share good practice in delivering effective SEND and inclusive provision within FE and skills, focusing on policies and approaches that create psychologically safe learning environments, strengthen professional resilience, and build partnership with employers and local skills systems, ensuring every learner, at every stage,¬†can¬†achieve.

This is an essential, full-day, onsite training course for anyone who may have First Aid responsibilities in the workplace or a general interest in first aid. This course is designed for people in the charity sector who want to receive training in emergency first aid and is especially suited for nominated first aiders in smaller, low risk working environments. raw.title: Designated Safeguarding Lead (DSL) EYRES MONSELL CHILDREN CENTRE/T Charlton
raw.desc_preview: Full day DSL Training (not for schools) for those work with children in Leicester, Leicestershire& Rutland @Eyres Monsell Children Centre/TC
raw.full_description: Full day DSL Training (not for schools) for those work with children in Leicester, Leicestershire& Rutland @Eyres Monsell Children Centre/TC Full day's training offered on 6 different dates (see below) in Eyres Monsell Children Centre (please DO NOT go to Community Centre) Weds 17th Sept Thursday 6th Nov Tuesday 20th Jan 2026 Thursday 5th March 2026 This course is designed for both DSL‚Äôs and deputy DSL‚Äôs that are new to the role, it can also be used as a refresher training. Designated Safeguarding Leads are also known as Designated Safeguarding Officer or Lead for Safeguarding there are many equivalents. (This training is not for school DSLs) This is an advanced level course for those that have already had Safeguarding Awareness training including the signs and indicators of abuse. The session will explore and provide clarity on the questions: what is the role of the DSL? What are the responsibilities of the role? Do these differ between different organisations? And if yes, should they? What is the relevant legislation and guidance underpinning this role? Why do people ‚Äòmiss‚Äô the signs and fail to take action? How do we overcome these barriers? How can we start to show that we are putting the learning from serious case reviews into practice? Moving on, it will cover key updates (the content of these will be dependent on what the Safeguarding Board identify at the time of the course as key information). It will then move on to ensure that participants are confident in identifying and responding to concerns. We will look at ‚Äòsigns of safety‚Äô in the referral context, record keeping, what might happen following a referral, the need to follow up and be persistent. We will also look at escalation procedures. In the afternoon we focus on Multi-agency working including information Sharing and give an overview of Safer Working Practice including recruitment. Exploring both serious case reviews and participants own experience of multi-agency working at all levels. We will dispel common myths around information sharing and share best practice. 'There will also be a chance to look at an audit of practice and to assess areas for development. Trainer: Tracy Charlton By the end of the course participants will: ‚Ä¢ Be clear of their safeguarding role and responsibilities as a DSL and the key safeguarding legislation and guidance. ‚Ä¢ Understand the barriers that can exist to taking action and have identified ways to overcome these and create a safe culture for staff and children. ‚Ä¢ Be confident in decisions about what action to take, what records to keep and what referrals to make when there is a concern. ‚Ä¢ Understand local processes and procedures, including escalation. ‚Ä¢ Have explored the necessity for multi-agency communication and effective multi-agency work to safeguard and protect children and have the confidence to challenge when needed. Objectives: ‚Ä¢ To be clear of your role and responsibilities as a DSL ‚Ä¢ Understand the Barriers that exist to staff taking action and identify ways to overcome these and create a safe culture for staff and children. ‚Ä¢ To start to be able to state how you as a DSL can put the learning from serious case reviews into practice. ‚Ä¢ To understand your responsibilities in relation to key local and national themes ‚Äì e.g, voice of the child, online safety, mental health, and the resources available to you. ‚Ä¢ Recap on the signs and indicators of abuse with a focus on the ‚Äòlived experience of the child‚Äô and factors creating additional vulnerability. ‚Ä¢ Understand local processes and procedures. ‚Ä¢ Identify the need for ‚Äòprofessional curiosity‚Äô and being conscious of ‚Äòdisguised compliance.‚Äô ‚Ä¢ Know how to respond and how to make a quality referral. ‚Ä¢ Identify how to keep effective records. ‚Ä¢ Demonstrate a commitment to Persistence ‚Äì notice, check, share, follow-up, escalate. ‚Ä¢ To understand the DSL‚Äôs responsibilities in terms of multi-agency working and information sharing. ‚Ä¢ To explore the why this is a persistent theme in serious case reviews - what are the myths and barriers and how to work to overcome these. ‚Ä¢ To look at safer working practice including recruitment. ‚Ä¢ Audit of practice and assessment of areas for development in your setting that you have identified as a result of this training. ‚Ä¢ Evaluation of Development and Learning. This training is not aimed at schools. Please e-mail us your full name after the training, if you would like a certificate.

raw.full_description: An evening of exquisite food, fine whisky, friendship and fun Our annual Burns Celebration is one of our favourite ‚Äì and most popular ‚Äì events of the year. It brings together our diverse College community for an evening of exquisite food, fine whisky, friendship and fun. Our Burns Celebration takes place just before Burns Night in celebration of Scotland‚Äôs most famous poet, Robert Burns. He wrote more than 550 poems and songs before his death in 1796 and is recognised today as ‚ÄòScotland‚Äôs national poet‚Äô. This special event will celebrate his life and work through poetry and music. To raise extra funds to support health projects in Malawi, there will be a raffle with exciting prizes on offer. The Burns Celebration will take place in the majestic College Hall, an atmospheric wood-panelled room dating from 1893. Designed by the renowned Scottish architect Sir J J Burnet (1857‚Äì1938), it is one of the finest examples of Victorian architecture anywhere in the city. We cater for a wide variety of dietary requirements. More information will be available during the booking process. Each ticket includes: Drink on arrival Three-course dinner Half a bottle of wine with your meal Entertainment (piper, poetry and music) Venue: Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow Dress code: Highland dress or lounge suits Start: 7pm; Finish: Midnight Tickets: ¬£70 per person Special early bird offer: ¬£10 off tickets until the end of November.
